Case Name: SHER SINGH @ PARTAPA VS. STATE OF HARYANA
Judge Names:
Hon'ble Mr. Justice Kurian Joseph, Hon'ble Mr. Justice Vikramajit Sen
*
HeadNote: Penal Code, 1860 - ss. 304B and 498A - Dowry death — Prosecution case that victim-wife committed suicide due to harassment for dowry by her husband and in-laws within one year of marriage ~ Two months prior to her death she informed her brothers of cruelty connected with dowry demand — Conviction and sentence of husband, brother-in-law and father-in-law of the victim u/ss. 304B and 498A by the trial court — High Court acquitting the brother-in-law and father-in- law of the victim, however, upholding the conviction and sentence of the husband — On appeal, held: Once the concomitants of dowry death are established or shown or proved by the prosecution, even by preponderance of possibility, the presumption of innocence is replaced by an assumption of guilt of the accused, whereupon a heavy burden is cast on the shoulders of the accused to displace the deemed culpability beyond reasonable doubt, and not merely by preponderance of evidence Prosecution has not shown/ presented and or proved even by preponderance of probabilities that the deceased had been treated with cruelty emanating from or founded on dowry demands — Ingestion of aluminium phosphate may have been accidental ~ Due to the insufficiency or the unsatisfactory nature of the facts or circumstances shown by the prosecution, burden of proving his innocence not shifted to the appellant ~ Thus, order of conviction and sentence of the appellant set aside.

HeadNote: Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963 — s. 2(vi), 2(viil), 5, 5A, 22 — Dealer — Winding up proceedings of a company in liquidation ~ Sales effected by Official Liquidator pursuant thereto — Liability of the Official Liquidator to pay sales tax - Held: By inviting tenders, for the sale of the assets of the Company, the liquidator intended to conduct a transfer of the goods in liquidation ~ Since the said transfer falls within the wide ambit of s. 2(vili)(), Company in liquidation is a “dealer” with regard to the transfer — In terms of s. 5, the Company in liquidation, as a dealer, would incur liability to pay sales tax at the point of first sale as incurred by any other dealer under the Act - Further, since the Official Liquidator merely steps into the shoes of the company in liquidation and performs his statutory functions in accordance with the directives of the Court, the “Official Liquidator’ is a “dealer” within the meaning of s. 2(viii) - in terms of r. 54 the person, in-charge of the business on behalf of the dealer, would be eligibie to sales tax in the same manner as it would have been leviable upon and recoverable from the dealer itself — Therefore, the liability to pay sales tax, would be on the Official Liquidator in the Same manner as the dealer, that is, the Company in liquidation — Kerala General Sales Tax Rules, 1963 - r. 54 —- Companies Act, 1956 — ss. 448, 456, 457 — Companies (Court) Rules, 1959.

HeadNote: Penal Code, 1860: s.302 r/w s.149; 304 Part-I - Allegation that accused persons committed murder of PW- 3's wife — Prosecution case was that PW-3 had purchased land for cattle shed from A-1 — Later their relations became bitter and A-1 started pressurizing PW-3 to vacate the land — On fateful day, accused armed with weapons barged in the cattle shed and started removing the iron sheets fixed on roof - Scuffle took place between PW-3 and accused persons — A- 1 set fire on the cattle shed — Wife of PW-3 present in cattle shed caught fire - When PW-3 tried to save his wife, A-2 inflicted axe biow on him — PW-3’s wife succumbed to burn injuries — Conviction u/s. 302 by courts below — Held: it was a fight on a spur of moment between the two male groups on the issue of taking possession of cattle shed with no intention to kill any one — Had the appellants not ablaze the cattle shed, the incident of death of PW-3's wife would not have occurred — In the absence of any overt act attributed to any of the appellants towards the deceased for inflicting any injury to her, the appellants could not have been convicted for an offence of murder so as to attract the rigour of s.302 — Instead they are liable to conviction u/s.304 Part I.

HeadNote: High Court of Jharkhand Rules, 2001 — r. 159 - r. 159 requiring the accused to surrender to the custody of the court before filing revision petition — Constitutional validity of - Held: Rule does not suffer from any infirmity — The general practice is that a revision against conviction and sentence is filed after an appeal is dismissed and the convicted person is taken into custody in Court itself - Object of the Rule is to ensure that a person who has been convicted by two courts obeys the law and does not abscond — Provision cannot thus, be held to be arbitrary in any manner — Provision is to regulate the procedure of the Court and does not, in any manner, conflict with the substantive provisions of the Cr.P.C. - Similar provision exists in the Supreme Court Rules, 1966 -— Rule does not affect the inherent power of the High Court to exempt the requirement of surrender in exceptional situations — Constitution of India, 1950 — Arts. 14, 21, 32 - Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 — ss. 397, 401. /
